title: Two objects. Same room. Two different temperatures?

multiple-choice.question: What does it mean when an object feels warm or cold to the touch?

options.label: A
options.text: The object is actually warm or cold.

options.label: B
options.text: The object is conducting heat towards or away from your hand.

options.label: C
options.text: The object is at a higher or lower temperature than the surrounding air.

options.label: D
options.text: The object is made of a material that is warm or cold to the touch.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the hard drive feel colder than the book, even though they were at the same temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: The hard drive was made of a colder material.

options.label: B
options.text: The hard drive was in a colder environment.

options.label: C
options.text: The hard drive conducted heat away from the hand faster than the book.

options.label: D
options.text: The book was made of a warmer material.

multiple-choice.question: What is thermoconductivity?

options.label: A
options.text: The rate at which heat is transferred from one object to another.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability of an object to retain heat.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability of an object to conduct electricity.

options.label: D
options.text: The rate at which an object cools down.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the ice cube melt faster on the aluminum block than on the plastic block?

options.label: A
options.text: The aluminum block was warmer than the plastic block.

options.label: B
options.text: The aluminum block conducted heat to the ice cube faster than the plastic block.

options.label: C
options.text: The plastic block was colder than the aluminum block.

options.label: D
options.text: The ice cube was smaller on the aluminum block.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason why a bath mat feels warmer than a towel after a shower in winter?

options.label: A
options.text: The bath mat is actually warmer than the towel.

options.label: B
options.text: The bath mat conducts heat less quickly away from the body.

options.label: C
options.text: The towel is made of a colder material.

options.label: D
options.text: The bath mat is made of a warmer material.

multiple-choice.question: What does it mean to feel temperature?

options.label: A
options.text: To feel the actual temperature of an object.

options.label: B
options.text: To feel the rate at which heat is conducted towards or away from the body.

options.label: C
options.text: To feel the texture of an object.

options.label: D
options.text: To feel the weight of an object.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the people in the experiment think the hard drive was colder than the book?

options.label: A
options.text: They were tricked by the appearance of the objects.

options.label: B
options.text: They were influenced by the temperature of the surrounding air.

options.label: C
options.text: They felt the rate at which heat was conducted away from their hands.

options.label: D
options.text: They were mistaken about the actual temperature of the objects.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using an infrared thermometer in the experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure the temperature of the objects.

options.label: B
options.text: To measure the rate at which heat is conducted.

options.label: C
options.text: To measure the texture of the objects.

options.label: D
options.text: To measure the weight of the objects.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the experiment with the ice cube on the aluminum and plastic blocks?

options.label: A
options.text: The ice cube melts faster on the plastic block.

options.label: B
options.text: The ice cube melts faster on the aluminum block.

options.label: C
options.text: The ice cube melts at the same rate on both blocks.

options.label: D
options.text: The ice cube does not melt on either block.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main conclusion of the experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: That objects can feel warmer or colder than they actually are.

options.label: B
options.text: That objects can conduct heat at different rates.

options.label: C
options.text: That temperature is not always what it seems.

options.label: D
options.text: That all objects are at the same temperature.

title: How the mantis shrimp can break glass

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Making a TED-Ed Lesson: Bringing a pop-up book to life

title: Can You Solve This?

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial task given by the speaker to the participants?

options.label: A
options.text: To propose a set of three numbers that follows a specific mathematical operation.

options.label: B
options.text: To guess the rule that the speaker has in mind based on a given sequence of three numbers.

options.label: C
options.text: To come up with a new sequence of three numbers that has no relation to the given sequence.

options.label: D
options.text: To solve a mathematical problem using the given sequence of three numbers.

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial sequence of three numbers given by the speaker?
What was the first proposed rule by the participants?
What was the speaker's response to the proposed rule "Multiply by 2"?

options.label: B
options.text: It is not the correct rule, but it follows the rule.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not the correct rule, and it does not follow the rule.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker did not respond to the proposed rule.

multiple-choice.question: What was the turning point in the conversation that led to the discovery of the correct rule?

options.label: A
options.text: When the speaker gave a hint about the rule.

options.label: B
options.text: When the participants proposed a set of numbers that did not follow their initial rule.

options.label: C
options.text: When the speaker revealed the correct rule.

options.label: D
options.text: When the participants asked the speaker to give them another sequence of numbers.

multiple-choice.question: What was the correct rule that the speaker had in mind?
What was the inspiration behind the speaker's video?

options.label: C
options.text: A book called "The Black Swan" by Nassim Taleb

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the concept of the "Black Swan"?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of proving a theory true.

options.label: B
options.text: The impossibility of proving a theory true and the unexpected nature of reality.

options.label: C
options.text: The need to confirm one's beliefs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice on how to approach theories and rules?

options.label: A
options.text: Try to confirm them as much as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: Try to disprove them as much as possible.

options.label: C
options.text: Ignore them and come up with new ones.

options.label: D
options.text: Only consider the ones that are widely accepted.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the importance of trying to disprove one's theories?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows one to confirm their biases.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows one to get at the truth and not fool oneself.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows one to come up with new theories.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows one to ignore the rules.

title: Corruption, wealth and beauty: The history of the Venetian gondola - Laura Morelli

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the distinctive look of the Venetian gondola?

options.label: A
options.text: The origins are well-documented in historical records.

options.label: B
options.text: The origins are lost to history, but it is believed to have evolved over centuries.

options.label: C
options.text: The origins are attributed to a single gondola maker.

options.label: D
options.text: The origins are influenced by other types of boats.

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary function of gondolas in Venice?

options.label: A
options.text: To transport goods and dignitaries through the city's canals.

options.label: B
options.text: To serve as a status symbol for wealthy Venetians.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a mode of transportation for the general public.

multiple-choice.question: Why were gondoliers often viewed negatively in historical documents?

options.label: A
options.text: They were known for their excellent navigation skills.

options.label: B
options.text: They were praised for their customer service.

options.label: C
options.text: They were accused of cursing, gambling, and extorting passengers.

options.label: D
options.text: They were admired for their boat-maintenance skills.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Venetian authorities decree that all but ceremonial gondolas be painted black in 1562?

options.label: A
options.text: To promote the gondola as a status symbol.

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the visibility of gondolas in the canals.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the durability of the gondolas.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the squero in the construction of gondolas?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a type of material used in gondola construction.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a family boatyard where gondolas were built.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a technique used to shape the gondola's frame.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a tool used to apply varnish to the gondola.

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the fire and water process in gondola construction?

options.label: A
options.text: To apply varnish to the gondola.

options.label: C
options.text: To achieve the gondola's distinctive profile.

options.label: D
options.text: To prepare the surfaces for painting.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the Venetian oarlock, or fórcola?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a simple wooden fork used to guide the oar.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a high-precision tool that allowed the gondolier to guide the oar into many positions.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a type of material used in oar construction.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a technique used to steer the gondola.

multiple-choice.question: Why did gondola makers begin to make the left side of the gondola wider than the right?

options.label: C
options.text: To counterbalance the force created by a single gondolier.

multiple-choice.question: What has contributed to the decline of authentic gondolas in Venice?

options.label: A
options.text: The increasing popularity of gondola travel.

options.label: B
options.text: The improvement of gondola construction techniques.

multiple-choice.question: What do the street signs in Venice's alleys contain that relate to the city's boat-building past?

options.label: A
options.text: Words in Italian dialect for the locations of old boatyards.

options.label: B
options.text: Words in Venetian dialect for the locations of old boatyards.

options.label: C
options.text: Pictures of gondolas and other boats.

title: What happens when you remove the hippocampus? - Sam Kean

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the renowned neurosurgeon who performed a partial lobotomy on Henry Molaison (H.M.) in 1953?
Why did Henry Molaison (H.M.) undergo a partial lobotomy surgery?
What part of the brain was removed during H.M.'s surgery, which was associated with emotion but whose function was unknown at the time?
What was the primary effect of the surgery on H.M.'s memory?

options.label: A
options.text: He lost most of his memories from the previous decade and was unable to form new ones.

options.label: B
options.text: He gained exceptional memory abilities and could recall every detail of his life.

options.label: D
options.text: He experienced minor memory lapses but could still form new memories.

multiple-choice.question: Who studied H.M. at his parents' home and made significant discoveries about his memory?
What distinction did Dr. Milner's findings shed light on regarding memory?

options.label: A
options.text: The difference between short-term and long-term memory

options.label: B
options.text: The difference between declarative and procedural memory

options.label: C
options.text: The difference between conscious and unconscious memory

options.label: D
options.text: The difference between visual and auditory memory

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the process of memory formation in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate sensory data is temporarily transcribed by neurons in the cortex, then travels to the hippocampus for strengthening, and finally is transferred back to the cortex for permanent storage.

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate sensory data is permanently stored in the cortex, then travels to the hippocampus for retrieval.

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate sensory data is temporarily stored in the hippocampus, then travels to the cortex for permanent storage.

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate sensory data is permanently stored in the hippocampus.

multiple-choice.question: What type of memory relies more on the basal ganglia and cerebellum, structures that were intact in H.M.'s brain?
What is the distinction between "knowing that" and "knowing how" in memory research?

options.label: A
options.text: The difference between declarative and procedural memory

options.label: B
options.text: The difference between short-term and long-term memory

options.label: C
options.text: The difference between conscious and unconscious memory

options.label: D
options.text: The difference between visual and auditory memory

multiple-choice.question: What happened to H.M.'s brain after his death?

options.label: A
options.text: It was preserved and scanned, then cut into individual slices and photographed to form a digital map.

options.label: B
options.text: It was donated to a medical school for educational purposes.

options.label: D
options.text: It was lost during the autopsy process.

title: Feedback loops: How nature gets its rhythms - Anje-Margriet Neutel

multiple-choice.question: What is the key element in the concept of feedback in the natural world?

options.label: A
options.text: A phenomenon called mutual exclusive interaction.

options.label: B
options.text: A phenomenon called mutual causal interaction.

options.label: C
options.text: A phenomenon called linear causal interaction.

options.label: D
options.text: A phenomenon called cyclical causal interaction.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the stable mass of organic matter that enriches the soil when plants die?
What type of feedback amplifies a particular effect or change from previous conditions?
What is an example of negative feedback in an ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: The buildup of humus in the soil.

options.label: B
options.text: The relationship between predators and their prey.

options.label: C
options.text: The effect of pesticides on insect populations.

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of deforestation on erosion.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the predator population when the prey population declines?
Why may spraying pesticides not be an effective long-term solution for controlling insect populations?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it kills all the insects.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it can trigger a host of other unexpected reactions.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to a feedback loop if one link is removed?
How do feedback loops in ecological systems interact with each other?

options.label: B
options.text: They play together, creating regular patterns.

options.label: D
options.text: They have no impact on each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an ecosystem with strong negative and positive feedback loops?
What can happen to an abandoned patch of farmland over time?

title: What can Schrödinger's cat teach us about quantum mechanics? - Josh Samani

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you throw a ball straight into the air?

options.label: A
options.text: It moves in a circular motion and lands in a different location.

options.label: B
options.text: It moves upward until it gets to some highest point, then it comes back down and lands in your hand again.

options.label: C
options.text: It stays suspended in the air and doesn't come back down.

options.label: D
options.text: It changes direction mid-air and lands in a different location.

multiple-choice.question: Why can't we answer questions about the physics of atoms based on our experience with everyday physics?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the physics of atoms is the same as the physics of macroscopic objects.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the physics that governs the behavior of systems at small scales is much different than the physics of macroscopic objects.

options.label: C
options.text: Because we don't have enough information about the physics of atoms.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the physics of atoms is too complex to understand.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between classical mechanics and quantum mechanics?

options.label: A
options.text: Classical mechanics deals with small-scale systems, while quantum mechanics deals with large-scale systems.

options.label: B
options.text: Classical mechanics deals with macroscopic objects, while quantum mechanics deals with small-scale systems.

options.label: C
options.text: Classical mechanics is more accurate than quantum mechanics.

options.label: D
options.text: Quantum mechanics is more accurate than classical mechanics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of superposition in quantum physics?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability of a system to be in multiple states at the same time.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability of a system to be in only one state at a time.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability of a system to change states quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability of a system to remain in the same state forever.

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of the Schrödinger's cat experiment?

options.label: C
options.text: The cat has a 50% chance of being alive or dead.

options.label: D
options.text: The cat is in a superposition state, both alive and dead at the same time.

multiple-choice.question: What is quantum entanglement?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability of two systems to be connected in such a way that the state of one system affects the state of the other system.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability of two systems to be independent of each other.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability of two systems to be in the same state at the same time.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability of two systems to be in different states at the same time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of entangling two cats in boxes?

options.label: A
options.text: Both cats will always be alive.

options.label: B
options.text: Both cats will always be dead.

options.label: C
options.text: One cat will always be alive, and the other cat will always be dead.

options.label: D
options.text: The outcome is random and unpredictable.

multiple-choice.question: How is it possible for entangled particles to communicate with each other even when they are separated by large distances?

options.label: A
options.text: Through a hidden connection that allows them to communicate instantaneously.

options.label: B
options.text: Through a physical connection that allows them to communicate slowly.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not possible for entangled particles to communicate with each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential application of quantum entanglement in quantum information science?

options.label: B
options.text: Quantum computing for cracking secret codes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential future development of quantum teleportation?

options.label: A
options.text: It will allow us to transport objects from one location to another instantly.

options.label: B
options.text: It will allow us to communicate with each other over long distances instantly.

options.label: C
options.text: It will allow us to escape to a safer galaxy.

options.label: D
options.text: It will allow us to travel through time.

title: Should I stay or should I switch doors?

multiple-choice.question: In the game show "Let's Make a Deal," what is the probability of winning the dream car if you stick with your initial choice?
What is the optimal strategy to win the dream car in the game show "Let's Make a Deal"?

options.label: B
options.text: Switch to the other unopened door

multiple-choice.question: In the game show "Let's Make a Deal," what is the probability of winning the dream car if you switch to the other unopened door?

options.text: To reveal the location of the dream car

options.label: C
options.text: To provide new information to the contestant

options.label: B
options.text: They are influenced by Monty Hall's behavior

options.label: C
options.text: They are uncertain about the location of the dream car

options.label: D
options.text: They are hesitant to take a risk

options.label: C
options.text: The probability of winning remains the same

options.label: D
options.text: The probability of winning becomes more uncertain

multiple-choice.question: What is the main conclusion of the Monty Hall problem?

options.label: A
options.text: The probability of winning is always 1/2

options.label: B
options.text: The probability of winning is always 1/3

options.label: C
options.text: Switching doors increases the probability of winning

options.label: D
options.text: Sticking with the initial choice is the best strategy

title: The past, present and future of the bubonic plague - Sharon N. DeWitte

multiple-choice.question: What was the estimated percentage of the world's population that was destroyed by the Black Death in the 14th century?
What was the name of the earlier epidemic that occurred in 541 CE, which was also caused by Yersinia pestis?
What is the primary reason why the medieval Black Death spread more quickly and was deadlier than modern instances of plague?

options.label: A
options.text: The disease was caused by a different pathogen.

options.label: B
options.text: The disease was spread by rodent fleas.

options.label: C
options.text: The disease was communicated directly from one person to another.

options.label: D
options.text: The disease was more contagious due to a mutation in the pathogen.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the rapid population growth in Europe during the High Middle Ages?

options.label: A
options.text: An increase in living standards and wages.

options.label: B
options.text: A decrease in living standards and wages due to famine, poverty, and poor health.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the Black Death on the gene pool of the surviving population?

options.label: A
options.text: The population became more susceptible to disease.

options.label: B
options.text: The population became more resistant to disease due to genetic mutations.

options.label: C
options.text: The population's gene pool remained unchanged.

options.label: D
options.text: The population became more prone to genetic disorders.

multiple-choice.question: What was the social impact of the Black Death on Europe?

options.label: A
options.text: The plague led to an increase in feudalism and a decline in social mobility.

options.label: B
options.text: The plague led to a weakening of feudalism and an increase in social mobility.

options.label: C
options.text: The plague had no significant social impact.

options.label: D
options.text: The plague led to a decline in agricultural production.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current threat posed by the bubonic plague?

options.label: A
options.text: The plague has been eradicated worldwide.

options.label: B
options.text: The plague continues to kill a few thousand people worldwide every year, and a drug-resistant strain has emerged.

options.label: C
options.text: The plague is only found in developing countries.

options.label: D
options.text: The plague is no longer a significant public health concern.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why the Black Death was so deadly in the 14th century?

options.label: A
options.text: The disease was caused by a highly contagious pathogen.

options.label: B
options.text: The population was malnourished and had poor health, making them more susceptible to infection.

options.label: C
options.text: The disease was spread by rodent fleas.

options.label: D
options.text: The disease was caused by a mutation in the pathogen.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of studying the genetic consequences of the Black Death?

options.label: A
options.text: It can help us understand how the plague spread in the 14th century.

options.label: B
options.text: It can help us develop new treatments for the plague.

options.label: C
options.text: It can help us understand how the plague affected the gene pool of the surviving population and potentially lead to new discoveries in disease resistance.

options.label: D
options.text: It can help us predict future pandemics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated percentage of Europeans who died during the Black Death?

title: How optical illusions trick your brain - Nathan S. Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: What is an optical illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: A magical phenomenon that changes the physical properties of an image.

options.label: B
options.text: A trick of the brain's visual system that alters our perception of reality.

options.label: C
options.text: A defect in the human eye that causes distorted vision.

options.label: D
options.text: A technique used in art to create 3D effects.

multiple-choice.question: What is lateral inhibition in the context of visual perception?

options.label: A
options.text: A process that reduces contrast between different visual stimuli.

options.label: B
options.text: A process that increases contrast between different visual stimuli.

options.label: C
options.text: A process that ignores visual information from the periphery.

options.label: D
options.text: A process that enhances visual information from the center of the visual field.

multiple-choice.question: Why do our brains give extra attention to edges in visual perception?

options.label: B
options.text: Because edges help us to recognize patterns.

options.label: C
options.text: Because edges can indicate the presence of objects that can help or harm us.

options.label: D
options.text: Because edges are irrelevant to visual perception.

multiple-choice.question: What assumption does the brain's visual cortex make about lighting in the environment?

options.label: A
options.text: That light comes from multiple sources.

options.label: B
options.text: That light comes from a single source shining down from above.

options.label: C
options.text: That light is diffuse and evenly distributed.

options.label: D
options.text: That light is irrelevant to visual perception.

multiple-choice.question: What is the fusiform face area in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: An area responsible for recognizing patterns.

options.label: B
options.text: An area responsible for recognizing faces.

options.label: C
options.text: An area responsible for processing visual information from the periphery.

options.label: D
options.text: An area responsible for processing auditory information.

multiple-choice.question: Why do we focus on the eyes and mouth when recognizing faces?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are the most distinctive features of a face.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are the most expressive features of a face.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are the most important features for recognizing emotions.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are the only features that matter for recognizing faces.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the brain's visual system in constructing our perception of reality?

options.label: A
options.text: To passively receive visual information from the environment.

options.label: B
options.text: To actively construct a tailored, edited vision of the world.

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore visual information that is irrelevant to our survival.

options.label: D
options.text: To enhance visual information that is relevant to our survival.

multiple-choice.question: How does the brain allocate cognitive energy in visual perception?

options.label: A
options.text: By spending equal amounts of energy on all visual stimuli.

options.label: B
options.text: By spending more energy on visual stimuli that are relevant to our survival.

options.label: C
options.text: By spending less energy on visual stimuli that are irrelevant to our survival.

options.label: D
options.text: By using assumptions about visual information to conserve energy.

multiple-choice.question: What do optical illusions reveal about the brain's visual system?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is defective and prone to errors.

options.label: B
options.text: That it is capable of constructing a accurate, objective representation of reality.

options.label: C
options.text: That it uses assumptions and shortcuts to construct a tailored, edited vision of the world.

options.label: D
options.text: That it is irrelevant to our perception of reality.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of the brain's visual system in constructing our perception of reality?

options.label: A
options.text: To create an accurate, objective representation of the world.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a tailored, edited vision of the world that is relevant to our survival.

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore visual information that is irrelevant to our survival.

options.label: D
options.text: To enhance visual information that is relevant to our survival.

title: The secret lives of baby fish - Amy McDermott

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of fish species that live on coral reefs?
Where do baby coral reef fish begin their life cycle?
What is the primary challenge faced by baby coral reef fish during their early stages?

options.label: C
options.text: Riding the right currents to find a suitable adult habitat

multiple-choice.question: How do larval fish maximize their chances of survival, according to recent research?

options.label: A
options.text: By drifting passively with ocean currents

options.label: B
options.text: By taking their fate in their own fins and actively navigating

options.label: C
options.text: By relying on their parents for protection

options.label: D
options.text: By settling on the first reef they encounter

multiple-choice.question: What sensory systems do larvae use to navigate towards their preferred adult habitats?

options.label: C
options.text: A complex suite of sensory systems, including sound and smell

multiple-choice.question: What happens when larvae find a suitable coral reef but conditions are not right?

options.label: A
options.text: They settle down and metamorphose into adults

options.label: B
options.text: They jump back up into higher water masses and ride on

options.label: C
options.text: They stay on the reef and try to adapt

multiple-choice.question: What is the "bungee system" used by larvae to settle on a coral reef?

options.label: A
options.text: A process of randomly dropping down to the reef and hoping for the best

options.label: B
options.text: A process of checking out the reef below and then jumping back up if conditions are not right

options.label: C
options.text: A process of using a specific type of algae to settle on the reef

options.label: D
options.text: A process of following a specific type of fish to the reef

multiple-choice.question: What is currently unknown about the geographic movements of individual larva?

options.label: A
options.text: The exact route they take to get to the reef

options.label: B
options.text: The environmental cues and behaviors they use to navigate

options.label: C
options.text: The time it takes for them to settle on the reef

multiple-choice.question: How do larvae distinguish between different environments, including adjacent reefs?
What is the current understanding of the secret lives of baby fish?

options.label: A
options.text: They are well understood and their behaviors are well documented

options.label: B
options.text: They are largely mysterious and their behaviors are not well understood

options.label: C
options.text: They are completely understood and their behaviors are fully documented

options.label: D
options.text: They are not important to the ecosystem
